Tennessee School for the Deaf; Marr, Thomas Scott, 1866-1936; Holman, Joseph W., 1891-1952; Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.); Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, structures, etc.; Nicholson, V. L.; Barber, Charles Irving, 1887-1962

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Marr & Holman worked mostly in Tennessee and Kentucky, designing some of the most prominent structures of the 1910s and 1920s. Included are the Belmont Theater, Sulphur Dell baseball park, Nashville Post Office (now the Frist Center for the Visual Arts), Tennessee Home for Feeble Minded Persons, and Tennessee School for the Deaf. The School for the Deaf held special significance for Thomas Scott Marr since he was himself deaf.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Construction; Construction workers; Dormitories; Buildings
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Knoxville (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Construction nearly complete on Cottage D, the boys' dormitory building, on the campus of the Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb. Scaffolding, ramps, and sawhorses give an indication of the flurry of construction activity associated with this project. Workers can also be seen on the roof of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr & Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: In 1922, 125 acres in south Knoxville (the Dickinson estate in Island Home Park) was acquired to be the new home of the Tennessee School for the Deaf. Marr & Holman, a prominent Nashville architectural firm, was hired to design the new campus buildings. (Thomas S. Marr had attended the Tennessee School for the Deaf from 1877 to 1884.) In 1926 this dormitory building was added. The contractor was V. L. Nicholson. Other structures would follow and expand the campus.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The boys' dormitory, Cottage D, at the Tennessee School for the Deaf with construction drawing to a close. Windows, doors, and front entry steps have all been added within the course of a month's construction, and no construction equipment is present in this image. Writing on the reverse side of the photograph includes details about furnishings in the dormitory.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee School for the Deaf -- Entrance to Negro Department's, "New School Building"
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Buildings; Schools; Educational facilities; Deaf persons; Deafness; Segregation
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education --Tennessee; School buildings -- Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Large brick school building used for the Negro Department at the Tennessee School for the Deaf. The building appears to be under construction. There are several large windows in front of the building, and one entrance. This addition was referred to as the "New School Building."

The Negro Department at the Tennessee School for the Deaf was established in 1881. It secured a permanent location in 1885 with the purchase of the Abner G. Jackson home on Dandridge Pike. Radical improvements took place in 1940, when a cement block extension was added to the main building. That addition, pictured here, contained an auditorium, classrooms, a domestic arts department, a shop, and the central heating plant. Principal Henry C. Edmunds helped with the construction.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Tennessee School for the Deaf Athletic Association bus
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: School buses; Vehicles; Transportation; Buildings; Schools
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Education -- Tennessee; Education -- History -- Tennessee; School buildings -- Tennessee; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; School buses; Athletics
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A passenger bus labeled "Tennessee School For The Deaf." It is parked in front of the Administration Building on the campus of the school. It is an all-steel, 28-passenger Wayne body on an International chassis, acquired for the school by its Athletic Association.

The Athletic Association of the Tennessee School for the Deaf revived an extant Bus Fund in the fall of 1938 and began seriously raising money to purchase a bus for the use of the athletic teams. The committee heading up this effort was composed of Chairman Conley Akin, Publicity Chariman J.M. Smith, Jr., and Treasurer Harley Bishop. Alumni, pupils, teachers, and friends contributed. The institution received their bus in the fall of 1940.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Deaf and Dumb Asylum
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cities & towns; Asylums; Historic buildings
Tennessee School for the Deaf -- Buildings; Wittemann, Adolph, 1845-1938; Cocke, John, 1772-1854; Morgan, Calvin, 1773-1851; Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, structures, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Postcard showing the Deaf and Dumb Asylum as of 1885. (Seventh of 13 images in a booklet called "Knoxville, Tenn.")

The Tennessee School for the Deaf (originally called the Tennessee School for the Deaf & Dumb or the Deaf & Dumb Asylum) was authorized by the state in 1844, following legislative efforts intiated by Sen. John Cocke of Grainger County. Merchant Calvin Morgan donated the property for the school, and construction began in 1846. The school's original location was known as "Old City Hall." In 1925 the school moved to its present 96-acre campus on the banks of the Tennessee River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Island Home, the Dickinson house located at the Tennessee School for the Deaf
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Houses; Dwellings; Historic buildings
Tennessee School for the Deaf -- Buildings; Dickinson, Perez, 1813-1901; Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, structures, etc.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Island Home, the Dickinson House, is the superintendent's residence on the Tennessee School for the Deaf's campus.

The home was built as a summer home for Col. Perez Dickinson's bride, Susan Penniman, in 1846. President Rutherford B. Hayes was a house guest there in 1877. The building was originally located on Col. Dickinson's 600-acre scientific farm overlooking the Holston River. The state bought 125 acres of the Dickinson property in 1922 as the site for the Tennessee School for the Deaf. The house has been used as the Superintendent's Residence since 1924.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Schools; Gymnasiums; Construction workers; Building construction
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Physical education and training
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The gymnasium at the Tennessee School for the Deaf under construction. The brick façade of the building is complete but no windows have been installed and no roof is visible. Stacks of building materials and a shed can be seen on the grounds. One African American worker can be seen standing at the corner of the building.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee School for the Deaf is a state-operated K-12 residential and day school for the deaf and hard of hearing established in 1844. Its current campus in the historic Island Park area of Knoxville was designed in 1928 by Thomas S. Marr, who was also deaf. Marr & Holman was a highly-acclaimed architectural firm from Nashville known for its traditional and art deco designs. They designed numerous buildings including the Nashville Post Office and the baseball grandstand at Sulphur Dell Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural drawings; Buildings; Schools; Dormitories; Rivers
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Architecture -- Designs and plans -- Presentation drawings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A design drawing of the landscape and buildings of the "Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb" by Marr & Holman and Barber & McMurry. Sections of the image are labeled, "Superintendent's residence" in the bottom left, "Dormitory for little boys" in the upper left, "School" in the top center, "Boiler & Laundry Building" in the upper right, and "Two dormitories for girls" in the bottom right. A label reading "Wiles Nashville, Tenn." is on the bottom right corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Tennessee School for the Deaf is a state-operated K-12 residential and day school for the deaf and hard of hearing established in 1844. Its current campus in the historic Island Park area of Knoxville was designed in 1928 by Thomas S. Marr, who was also deaf. Marr & Holman was a highly-acclaimed architectural firm from Nashville known for its traditional and art deco designs. They designed numerous buildings including the Nashville Post Office and the baseball grandstand at Sulphur Dell Park.

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Gymnasiums; Building construction; Schools; Construction workers
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Physical education and training
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The gymnasium at the Tennessee School for the Deaf under construction. Only the framework and sections of the foundation are completed. Numerous building materials and workmen can be seen on the site. A shed can be seen in the distance and another building can be seen on the left. The roof of another building is visible in the lower right corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929

Marr & Holman was a highly-acclaimed architectural firm from Nashville known for its traditional and art deco designs. Tennessee School for the Deaf; Marr, Thomas Scott, 1866-1936; Holman, Joseph W., 1891-1952; Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.); Knoxville (Tenn.) -- Buildings, structures, etc.; Nicholson, V. L.; Barber, Charles Irving, 1887-1962
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cottages A and B under construction on the campus of the Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Marr & Holman worked mostly in Tennessee and Kentucky, designing some of the most prominent structures of the 1910s and 1920s. Included are the Belmont Theater, Sulphur Dell baseball park, Nashville Post Office (now the Frist Center for the Visual Arts), Tennessee Home for Feeble Minded Persons, and Tennessee School for the Deaf. The School for the Deaf held special significance for Thomas Scott Marr since he was himself deaf.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Design sketch of the campus of the Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Architectural drawings; Buildings; Schools; Dormitories; Rivers
Tennessee School for the Deaf; Deaf -- Education -- Tennessee; Architecture -- Designs and plans -- Presentation drawings
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A design drawing of the landscape and buildings of the "Tennessee School for the Deaf and Dumb. Island Home. Knoxville, Tenn." by Marr & Holman and Barber & McMurry. Sections of the image are labeled: "Supt's Residence" in the bottom left, "Little Boys' Dormitory" in the upper left, "School" in the center, "Boiler House" in the upper right, and "Girls' Dormitories" in the bottom right. A label reading "Wiles Nashville, Tenn." is on the bottom right corner.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Marr and Holman, Architects (Nashville, Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Marr and Holman Architectural Firm Records, 1911-1929

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The grounds of the Tennessee School for the Deaf early into the construction of the facilities. The landscape is largely wooded and a few construction elements can be seen. oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cottages A and B on the grounds of the Tennessee School for the Deaf. The two buildings are shown in the early stages of construction, with only the foundations completed. Building supplies are also visible on the grounds.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The grounds of the Tennessee School for the Deaf early in the construction of the facilities. Several sites are seen in various stages of completion.
